description: From Middle English bath, baþ, from Old English bæþ (“bath”), from Proto-West Germanic *baþ, from Proto-Germanic *baþą (“bath”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰeh₁- (“to warm”). Corresponding inherited verbs are beath and bathe.

entries.meaning: A tub or pool which is used for bathing: bathtub.
A building or area where bathing occurs.
examples: Among the ancients, the public baths were of amazing extent and magnificence.
The master bath has two sinks.

entries.meaning: The body of liquid one bathes in.
(by extension) A substance or preparation in which something is immersed.
examples: a bath of heated sand, ashes, steam, or hot air

verbs.description: bath (third-person singular simple present baths, present participle bathing, simple past and past participle bathed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Commonwealth) To wash a person or animal in a bath.
(intransitive, informal, Commonwealth) To bathe (oneself); to have a bath.
(historical units of measure) A former Hebrew unit of liquid volume (about 23 L or 6 gallons).
examples: Ye shall have just balances, and a just ephah, and a just bath. The ephah and the bath shall be of one measure, that the bath may contain the tenth part of an homer, and the ephah the tenth part of an homer: the measure thereof shall be after the homer.
